text: Craigmount School was a private school originally for boys, but for most of its history for girls, in Edinburgh. It opened in 1874 and closed in 1966. ==History== Craigmount was founded in Edinburgh in 1874 as a school for boys. In 1884, it was re-opened as a boarding school for girls. During the Second World War and the immediate post-war years (from 1939–52), the school was at Scone Palace, Perthshire. At the end of the summer term, 1952, it moved to Minto in the Borders, leasing Minto House. In 1962, Minto House was purchased for £20,000. In 1966, the school was closed.National Library of Scotland Inventory Acc.12271 Craigmount School ==Notable alumni== *Thomas Maule Guthrie, (died 30 March 1943) was a Scottish Liberal Party politician.The Liberal year book, Volume 18, Page 62, 1922 (Liberal Publication Dept:Great Britain) *James Fullarton Muirhead (1853–1934), writer of travel guides, longtime associate of the Baedeker publishing house. *Mason Scott, rugby union international for EnglandMarshall, Francis, Football; the Rugby union game, p321, (1892) (London Paris Melbourne, Cassell and company, limited) *William Martin Scott, rugby union international for EnglandMarshall, Francis, Football; the Rugby union game, p321, (1892) (London Paris Melbourne, Cassell and company, limited) *Henry Springmann, rugby union international for EnglandMarshall, Francis, Football; the Rugby union game, p404-405, (1892) (London Paris Melbourne, Cassell and company, limited) *Archibald Williamson, 1st Baron Forres, Scottish businessman and politicianGeorge Edward Cokayne, Vicary Gibbs, The complete peerage of England, Scotland, Ireland, Great Britain and the United Kingdom: extant, extinct, or dormant, Volume 13, page 375 Editors: Vicary Gibbs, Baron Thomas Evelyn Scott-Ellis Howard de Walden; (The St. Catherine press, ltd.) 1940 ==References== Category:Defunct secondary schools in Edinburgh Category:Defunct Schools in Perth and Kinross Category:Defunct secondary schools in the Scottish Borders Category:Educational institutions established in 1874 Category:Defunct independent schools in Scotland Category:Defunct independent schools in Edinburgh Category:Defunct boarding schools in Scotland Category:1874 establishments in Scotland
